data.title: The Patriots (1994)
data.meta_description: Ariel, a young French Jew, decides to leave his family to go to Israel and secretly become an agent of Mossad, the Israeli secret service. After years of training, his first mission is in Paris to steal secrets from Remy Prieur, a French atomic scientist.
data.text:
He wants to check if his creation is not an error.

A chilling tale of espionage and the complexity of loyalty. Focused on a conflicted, French-born Mossad agent who is assigned to turn a Jewish U.S. intelligence analyst into a spy for Israel in a major breach of the countries’ longtime allyship.

Based on true events, and notably framed by an escalation of conservatism in the early 1980’s with the respective rises of Reaganism and Likud. As the young Mossad prince journeys deeper into a scandalous operation, the question is begged: how far will one go for their country, or for their people — which is often a nuanced distinction for us Members of the Tribe. And, when it’s all…

An antispectacular but fascinating journey into the mystery of intelligence agencies along a young recruit, specifically in Israeli services during their "exciting" 80s (Operation Opera, the Jonathan Pollard case).

If this wasn't thrilling enough on its own, there's even a touch of fantasm: the secret agent being french or the usual sexy prostitute (a shortly seen Sandrine Kiberlain who demonstrates great presence). Too bad the tool is also promoted to love interest for the initially idealistic hero while he's slowly waking up to the reality of his world. This last point also serves as a roadmap to a film that "lacks" any general intrigue.

Another downside would be the mission set in the USA, making most of the second half…
